headline: The Erasmus Experience
text: In this timeline, you will get to learn about programme that was developed to support European student movility with the increasingly unified European system of higher education and why this experience is a once in a lifetime opportunity.

headline: Erasmus of Rotterdam
text:
Born in the danish city of Rotterdam, Desiderius Erasmus Roterodamus was a Dutch philosopher and catholic theologian. At his time he was already considered one of the greatest scholars of the northern Renaissance. As a Catholic priest, he was an important figure in classical scholarship who wrote in a pure Latin style.

The European Community Network for Academic Exchanges is also called the Erasmus Programme in honor of the multinational and pro-European character of the humanist philosopher.

headline: Mamma Erasmus
text: In 1958, Sofía Corradi finished her university studies with a Master’s degree at Columbia University, New York, which she was able to attend thanks to an exchange scholarship. But when she returned to Italy, her university refused to validate the exams she had done abroad. Corradi then decided to look for signatures by dozens of firms to get the compatibility of studies in the world. And not only that, but having experienced first-hand the profound and positive change that entails a cultural exchange, she began to devise a plan that would lay the seed for what would later become the Erasmus programme.

headline: Sofía Corridi: laying the foundation of the experience
mediaUrl: ErasmusPlus changes your personality, helps you develop critical thinking, and new ways of looking at others.Sofía Corridi, pioneer of the Erasmus experience

headline: What is Erasmus? Erasmus programme: the beginning of the experience
text: The Erasmus Programme (EuRopean Community Action Scheme for the Mobility of University Students) is the European Union student exchange programme. 1987 was the year the programme was put into work, with the intention of offering university students the opportunity to learn and enrich their knowledge by travelling and studying in other countries of the European continent.

headline: Erasmus in Spain: First years
text: During its first year, the Erasmus programme involved 11 Member States: Belgium, Denmark, Germany, Greece, France, Ireland, Italy, the Netherlands, Portugal, Spain and the United Kingdom. A total of 3,244 students participated in that first year. The first Spanish students to leave Erasmus did so in 1988. One of them was Pedro Vidal-Aragon, who recounts his experience in this Facebook video. Every year more students and teachers benefited from the program and in 2002 the total number of million Erasmus students was reached since the project began in 1987.

headline: Erasmus+
text:
What is Erasmus+? Erasmus+ is the EU's programme to support education, training, youth and sport in Europe. The 2021-2027 programme places a strong focus on social inclusion, the green and digital transitions, and promoting young people’s participation in democratic life. It supports priorities and activities set out in the European Education Area, Digital Education Action Plan and the European Skills Agenda. The programme also,

  • Supports the European Pillar of Social Rights
  • Implements the EU Youth Strategy 2019-2027
  • Develops the European dimension in sport
Also, Erasmus+ offers mobility and cooperation opportunities in,
  • Higher education
  • Vocational education and training
  • School education (including early childhood education and care)
  • Adult education
  • Youth
  • and Sport

headline: Objectives of Erasmus
text: The programme has some specific objectives, the general one being to support, through lifelong learning, the educational, professional and personal development of people in education, training, youth and sport, in Europe and beyond, thereby contributing to sustainable growth, quality jobs and social cohesion, to driving innovation, and to strengthening European identity and active citizenship.

headline: Objectives of Erasmus
text:
On a more specific note, we have:

  • Promote learning mobility of individuals and groups, as well as cooperation, quality, inclusion and equity, excellence, creativity and innovation at the level of organisations and policies in the field of education and training.
  • Promote non-formal and informal learning mobility and active participation among young people, as well as cooperation, quality, inclusion, creativity and innovation at the level of organisations and policies in the field of youth.
  • Promote learning mobility of sport staff, as well as cooperation, quality, inclusion, creativity and innovation at the level of sport organisations and sport policies.

headline: Countries that take part in the program
text:
When the programme started in 1987, there were only 11 countries taking part: Belgium, Denmark, Germany, Greece, France, Ireland, Italy, The Netherlands, Portugal, Spain, The United Kingdom. Since then, several countries have joined the programme.

  • 1988: Luxembourg
  • 1992: Austria, Finland, Iceland, Norway, Sweden
  • 1994: Liechtenstein
  • 1998: Cyprus, Czech Republic, Hungary, Poland
  • 1999: Bulgaria, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Slovenia
  • 2000: Malta
  • 2004: Turkey
  • 2009: Croatia
  • 2014: The Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia
  • After 2014: North Macedonia, Republic of Turkey, Republic of Serbia
The rest of the countries are partnering countries.

headline: What happens when you do an Erasmus?
text: Here we will show you some of the advantages and disadvantages that come with doing an Erasmus exchange. We will share tips, tricks and some of our own experiences!

headline: Advantages: Traveling
text: You have the chance to get to know places you have never been before and the culture of that place. Walking through the streets, which have a lot of history. You also get to experience this with the people you get to meet on the Erasmus programme. You’ll start as friends, but end up with a family.

headline: Advantages: Experience
text: The Erasmus programme is a once in a lifetime experience. Staying away from family and friends sometimes can be difficult, but this experience gives you the opportunity to do one of the most important things, we need to learn and need to step out of our comfort zone.

headline: Advanatges: Language
text: The Erasmus experience gives you the opportunity to first, learn or improve if you already have knowledge about a language. Having a language to add to your resume is always welcomed, as it can improve your chances to one day land on a job application and even get that job. That same logic can be applied to internships, where you can show what you know, and then we begin with the circle of opportunities.

headline: Disadvantages: Financial struggles
text: Erasmus program provides an amount of money; the amount depends on the country you're going to, but it can really help. Most of the time this money only covers your rent and for the other expenses of living, you have to cover this yourself. When you are in a new culture you want to experience it all, and will most likely be pricey. Think of all the trips, partying and food you are going to buy. It is best to prepare yourself for these expenses.
mediaCaption: Tips on how to save money during Erasmus

headline: Disadvantages: Tourist phase
text: The Honeymoon phase. When you first arrive in a country, everything looks magical and amazing. You will endure most of the annoying things and focus on the magical part because everything is so new and bright. Later on you will realise that you're living in a new place. Everything that seemed so nice, can now annoy you and it has lost its sparkle. After a while you will start to settle down, and experience the country for what it is. When you have accepted all the bad things, you will start enjoying your stay again.

headline: Disadvantages: High expectations
text: You shouldn't rely your happiness on a country you will move to, because it is not enough. If you want to move abroad and leave your problems behind, spoiler alert! You won't be able to do that. Problems don't have borders, don't expect a new country to magically make it disappear. So one of the most important things to remember is you have to work for your happiness; don't expect it to happen by itself.

headline: 35th anniversary of the Erasmus programme
text:
To celebrate the 35th anniversary of the programme, The European Commission decided to create a commemorative coin with an unique design. The winning impression received over 22.000 votes and it is designed by Mr. Joaquín Jiménez. On the obverse will appear Erasmus of Rotterdam on a beam of links with the number 35, as well as the legends: 1987-2022, ERASMUS PROGRAMME, SPAIN.

1.000.000 coins will be minted.
mediaCaption: <a href="https://ec.europa.eu/newsroom/ecfin/items/708545"tile="">Commemorative coin for 35th anniversary of Erasmus programme</<>

headline: The Erasmus+ in first hand
text: When considering doing this kind of change, there are always doubts and questions. Here we show a few students that are loving the experience first hand in San Sebastián, a beautiful city in the north of Spain. We hope that their experience and testimonies help you!
